questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with painful restriction of movements of her left hip. She had a history of a fall a few months back which she ignored. A recent radiograph is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray showing flattening of the femoral head is suggestive of avascular necrosis. It is most commonly seen after a fracture neck of femur. 

The patient complains of pain and walks with a limp. The condition is treated by a total hip replacement. If untreated, osteoarthritis of the hip develops.

The image below shows the crescent sign, which is caused by the necrotic and repair processes that occur during avascular necrosis.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A patient presented with non-union of tibial fracture. The orthopedician suggested treatment by providing stability using a cast or brace. Which of the following type of nonunion does the patient most likely has?
questions.solution:
Stabilization using casts and braces are used in the treatment of hypertrophic nonunion.  

Management of nonunion:

  • Hypertrophic nonunion: Stabilization to allow chondrocyte-mediated mineralization of the fibrocartilage between fracture ends. With stabilization, healing usually occurs by 8 weeks.
  • Oligotrophic nonunion: Correcting the issues related to bone contact through mechanical compression or bone grafting to close the defects. In some cases, a combination of biologic and mechanical methods is used.
  • Atrophic nonunion: Autogenous bone graft or BMP to provide biologic stimulus at the fracture site. The other procedure done is debridement or excision of the non-vital bone ends. 
  • Pseudoarthrosis: Debridement of the pseudoarthrosis, opening of the medullary canal and providing more stability usually with compression at the nonunion site. In some cases, biologic stimulation may be helpful to promote healing.

questions.text: Which of the following are not true about fractures in children?

choices.text: Fractures take longer duration to heal in children
Children are less likely to experience morbidity from immobilization
Children are less compliant with activity restrictions
Impending compartment syndrome should be managed urgently

questions.solution:
In general, fractures in children, including physeal injuries, heal more rapidly than in adults, and they are less likely to experience morbidity or mortality from prolonged immobilization. Children are also often less compliant with postoperative activity restrictions, making cast immobilization a necessary adjunct to therapy.

Injuries involving neurovascular compromise or impending compartment syndrome should be managed urgently. Intra-articular fractures (such as Salter–Harris types III and IV) require anatomic reduction to restore the articular surface and prevent epiphyseal–metaphyseal cross union.

questions.text: The rotator interval in the shoulder is between _____
questions.solution:
The rotator interval is defined as the triangular area in the anterior and superior shoulder where no rotator cuff tendons are present. As such, the interval is bounded by the supraspinatus superiorly, the subscapularis inferiorly, and the coracoid medially. The apex of the triangle is marked laterally by the transverse humeral ligament. The coracohumeral ligament, biceps tendon, and superior glenohumeral ligament are found in the rotator interval.

The rotator interval is altered in pathologic states and has been found to be contracted in patients with adhesive capsulitis and expanded in those with shoulder instability.

The following image depicts the rotator cuff and rotator interval.

questions.text: What is the preferred management in an adult with a Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?

choices.text: Closed reduction with above elbow cast
Closed reduction with below elbow cast

questions.solution:
Galeazzi fracture-dislocation in an adult is managed by internal fixation with compression plating of the radius. In children, closed reduction is usually successful.

Note: Galeazzi's sign is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip where the infant's knees are flexed and approximated when lying down. One knee is higher than the other in developmental dysplasia.

The below image shows Galeazzi's sign. 

Related Pearl: Fractures of necessity

Fractures of necessity are those that require surgery for management. These include:

  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus 
  • Displaced fractured of olecranon and patella
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation 
  • Monteggia fracture in adults
  • Intra-articular fractures

questions.text: Which of the following is known as Bowler's thumb?

choices.text: Fracture dislocation of the neck of first metacarpal
Injury of the abductor pollicis longus tendon
Fracture of the base of first metacarpal

questions.solution:
Bowler’s thumb is a perineural fibrosis caused by repetitious compression of the ulnar digital nerve of the thumb while grasping a bowling ball.

Tingling and hyperesthesia around the pulp accompany this condition. A palpable lump that is exceedingly tender and at times accompanied by distal skin atrophy usually is present.

Early awareness of the cause can lead to protection of the thumb by a shield or splint and rest from bowling to help reduce the symptoms and to prevent the condition from becoming chronic. Occasionally, neurolysis and dorsal transfer of the nerve become necessary.

questions.text: A young sportsman presented with pain in his right elbow. On examination, Cozen's test was positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with positive Cozen's test is suggestive of tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis).

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: Swimmer’s view radio-graph is useful for evaluating:
questions.solution:
Swimmer’s view can enhance the clarity of radiographs involving the cervicothoracic junction by eliminating overlapping shadows of the deltoid and glenohumeral joint.

Open mouth view is for assessing odontoid process.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with posterior hip dislocation. Which of the following reduction methods is not used for the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Kocher’s maneuver is used for the management of shoulder dislocation. 

Reduction of hip dislocation (closed or open) should ideally be performed within 6 hours to prevent osteonecrosis of the hip joint.

Methods of closed reduction for posterior hip dislocation are:

1. Allis maneuver- traction applied opposite to the direction of deformity

 

2. Stimson maneuver- downward pressure to the flexed knee (patient is prone and at the edge of the table)

 

3. Bigelow maneuver- longitudinal traction with pressure on ASIS to stabilize the pelvis

 

4. East Baltimore lift maneuver- anterior force on the flexed knee (doctor's and assistant's place hands below the flexed knee)

questions.text: A radiograph of a patient with knee pain following an RTA revealed a floating knee. Which of the following injuries are likely to cause this condition?

choices.text: Fracture of  lower end of femur and dislocation of patella
Fracture of lower end of femur and upper end of tibia
Complete tear of medial and lateral collateral ligaments
Complete tear of anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.solution:
Fracture of lower end of femur and upper end of tibia can result in a floating knee.

It refers to the knee that is separated from the femur and tibia. It usually results from motor vehicle accidents.

questions.text: The Weber classification characterizes fractures of _____
questions.solution:
Classification of malleolar fracture of ankle developed by Danis and modified by Weber describes the injury based on the location of the lateral malleolar fracture.

Fractures may be classified as A, B, or C with a fracture below, at the level of, or above the syndesmosis respectively.

questions.text:
Keeping the fixation techniques for lateral malleolar fractures in mind, match the following correctly:

Column A: 1)Fibular fractures 2)Long oblique fracture 3)Low transverse fracture 4)Both malleoli

Column B: a)Two lag screws b)Tension band wiring and lag screw c) One-third semi-tubular plate and screws d)Single malleolar screw
questions.solution:
The fixation techniques for lateral malleolar fractures are:

  • Fibular fractures- one third semi-tubular plate 3.5 mm and screws or multiple 3.5 mm lag screws
  • Long oblique fracture- Two lag screws
  • Low transverse fracture- Single 4.5 mm malleolar screw
  • Both malleoli fracture- Tension band wiring for the lateral malleolar fracture and 4 mm lag screw for associated medial malleolar fracture.

questions.text: A 45-year old patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis presented to the clinic with the following deformity. What is it called?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is the hallux valgus. It is caused due to the excessive lateral deviation of the great toe with the prominence of the head of the first metatarsal.

It can be congenital or a consequence of rheumatoid arthritis or excessive usage of footwear with narrow toe space.

On the contrary, hallux varus is the excessive medial deviation of the great toe.

In gout, there is redness and swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint but there is no lateral deviation of the toe.

questions.text: A patient with a spinal injury presents with decreased sensation over the radial aspect of the forearm, thumb, and index finger. There is weakness of wrist extension on examination. Which nerve root has been damaged here?
questions.solution:
The C6 nerve root has been damaged in this case of loss of sensation over the radial aspect of forearm and weakened wrist extension.

Related Pearl: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb

Key Sensory Areas:

  • C5 - Upper lateral part of arm
  • C6 - Palmar pad of thumb
  • C7 - Pad of index finger
  • C8 - Pad of little finger
  • T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: What is an indication for observation in the treatment of scoliosis?

choices.text: Curve of more than 40 degrees in skeletally immature persons
Curve of 30-40 degrees in skeletally immature persons
Curve less than 20 degrees in skeletally immature persons
Curve more than 50 degrees in skeletally immature persons.

questions.solution:
Generally Accepted Guidelines for Observation in scoliosis:

  • Curves of less than 20° in skeletally immature persons are examined every 6 months.
  • Curves less than 20° in skeletally mature persons require no further evaluation.
  • Curves more than 20° in skeletally immature patients should be examined every 3–4 months.
  • Curves between 30–40° in skeletally mature persons do not require treatment. However, they are examined radiographically for progression every 2–3 years.

Indications for surgery in Scoliosis:

  • Curves >50° in skeletally mature patients
  • Curves >10° with marked rotations
  • Double major curves >30°

questions.text: Which of the following patients with disc prolapse have an absolute indication for surgery?

choices.text: Patient with sciatica not improving with epidural steroid injection
Patient that is diagnosed with cauda equina syndrome
Patient with progressive loss of sensation in the lower limbs

questions.solution:
Cauda equina syndrome is the only absolute and urgent indication for surgery in disc prolapse.

The relative indications for elective surgery in disc prolapse include:

  • Failed conservative management
  • Progressive neurological deficit
  • Recurrent episodes of incapacitating sciatica
  • Pain not relieved by complete rest from activities

The aim of the surgery is to relieve the pressure on the nerve root. The prolapsed disc is removed (discectomy), followed by stabilization of the spine.  

In most cases of disc prolapse, conservative treatment is given. Conservative therapy for this condition includes:

  • Bed rest
  • Heat
  • Ice
  • Analgesics
  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Antidepressants
  • Muscle relaxants
  • Epidural steroids

questions.text: Which of the following is a differential diagnosis for tuberculous arthritis of the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Septic arthritis of low grade and rheumatoid arthritis are other causes for monoarthritis of the hip joint and thereby are important differential diagnoses to be kept in mind.

Even an inguinal lymphadenopathy or psoas abscess may present with a flexion deformity of the hip because of the spasm of iliopsoas.

Congenital dislocation of the hip, coxa vara, and Perthes disease are other causes of a limp at that age.

questions.text: Which among the marked arrows in the given posterior view of knee joint, indicate anterior cruciate ligament?
questions.solution:
Given image shows the posterior aspect of knee joint. Hence, the ligament which is going toward anterior surface of tibia (B) is ACL.

(A) is attached to the posterior surface of tibia and hence it is posterior cruciate ligament.

(C) is the meniscus and (D) is lateral collateral ligament.

The black arrowhead and the black arrow when compared, shows non-uniform loss of cartilage, which is a key pathological feature of osteoarthritis.

The red arrow demonstrates the osteophyte.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Paget's disease. X-ray of the patient is given below. In which phase of the disease is the patient at?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows blade of grass deformity seen in the osteolytic phase of Paget's disease.

An initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization. Radiographically, this manifests as an advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass or flame shaped lesion.

The second phase is a period of very active bone formation and resorption. It is characterised by normal lamellar bone replaced with haphazard (woven) bone.

In the final sclerotic phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a hard, dense, less vascular mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget’s disease.

The arrow mark in the following image indicates blade of grass appearance.

questions.text: A newborn baby is found to have deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following findings would you not expect in him?

choices.text: Loss of abduction of the arm
Loss of lateral rotation of the arm
Loss of sensation in the lateral 2 fingers
Loss of flexion of the elbow

questions.solution:
The image shows Erb's palsy (waiter's tip deformity). In this condition, there is a loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid, and not in the lateral 2 fingers.

It is caused by injury to C5, C6, and rarely C7. It is seen most commonly in babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery.

The following are seen in Erb's palsy:

  • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Loss of flexion of the elbow
  • Loss of supination of the forearm
  • Loss of biceps, supinator, and inverse supinator jerks
  • Loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

questions.text: What happens to the nerve conduction in case of carpal tunnel syndrome?

choices.text: Absence of any transmitted impulse across the suspected site
Impulse transmission is not affected as it is only a compressive pathology

questions.solution:
• Absence of any transmitted impulse across the suspected site is an indicator of complete nerve injury.
  • The conduction velocity may simply be delayed in compressive nerve lesions such as carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding gout?

choices.text: More common in males than females
Abrupt fall in uric acid levels can precipitate an attack of gout
Chronic gouty arthritis is the most common clinical manifestation of gout

questions.solution:
Acute gouty arthritis is the most common clinical manifestation of gout, not chronic.

It is more common in men than in women. An abrupt fall in uric acid levels will precipitate an attack, as uric acid itself suppresses inflammatory cytokines.

Inflamed Heberden's or Bouchard's nodes may be the first manifestation of gouty arthritis.

Heberden and Bouchard nodes are also usually seen in osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with Ewing's sarcoma is on chemotherapy. Which of the following is an indicator of poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
Fever is one of the indicators for poor prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

Indicators of poor prognosis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Presence of distant metastasis - worst prognostic factor
  • Size and location of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anaemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Raised ESR
  • Male child and age 12–15 years

Histologic grade is of no prognostic significance because all Ewing's sarcomas are considered high grade.

Note: High levels of beta 2 microglobulin is an indicator of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common pulmonary manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is pleuritis.

The image below shows pleural effusion secondary to pleuritis in a patient with rheumatoid arthritits.

questions.text: Identify one of the cause of condition marked by small arrow in the radiograph.
questions.solution:
The above radiograph depicts ‘vertebra plana'. It is loss of height of the vertebral body both anteriorly and posteriorly (small arrows). It is seen in eosinophilic granuloma.

questions.text: The prosthesis used for above knee amputation is _____
questions.solution:
• Quadrilateral socket prosthesis is commonly used for above knee amputation.
  • Patellar Tendon Bearing Prosthesis is used for below knee amputation.
  • Canadian Syme's Prosthesis is used as a below knee prosthesis after Syme's amputation.
  • Shoefillers are used in partial foot amputations.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard for guiding antibiotic therapy in a case of osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Bone biopsy followed by tissue culture remains the gold standard method for guiding antibiotic therapy in case of osteomyelitis.  

A blood culture may be used to guide antibiotic therapy for hematologically acquired osteomyelitis. However, due to higher specificity in comparison to blood culture, a bone biopsy is considered the gold standard method of investigation. 

Wound swab is not a definitive method to confirm the origin of bacterial infection because the organism need not necessarily contaminate the wound. Similarly, a negative sinus tract culture also does not rule out the possibility of an infection on the inside as it is not essential for the organism to travel up to the surface.

questions.text: According to Wright and Moll's scheme, which pattern is not included in the classification of psoriatic arthritis?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric polyarthritis is not included in the classification of psoriatic arthritis.

  • Arthritis of the DIP joints
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis
  • Symmetric polyarthritis
  • Axial involvement such as spine and sacroiliac joints
  • Arthritis mutilans, a destructive form of arthritis

questions.text: Which of these is not a part of the terrible triad of the elbow?

choices.text: Fracture of coronoid process of ulna

questions.solution:
The terrible triad of the elbow does not include fracture of olecranon. 

The terrible triad of the elbow or Hotchkiss triad includes:

  1. Posterior dislocation of the elbow
  2. Radial head fracture
  3. Fracture coronoid process of the ulna

Note: Unhappy triad of the knee occurs due to a lateral blow to the knee causing injury to the anterior cruciate ligament, medial meniscus, and medial collateral ligament.

questions.text: What is the right order of correction of deformities in an infant with CTEV?
questions.solution:
The right order of correction of CTEV is cavus followed by adduction, then varus, and lastly equinus (CAVE).

An incorrect sequence of correction or overtreatment of CTEV can result in the development of the rocker-bottom foot. It is characterized by a prominent heel and a convex sole.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 3-year-old with genu varum?
questions.solution: Dynamic bracing should be done for a 3-year-old with genu varum.

questions.text: Which among the following is an early radiographic finding in spinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The reduction of disc space between the vertebrae is an early radiographic finding in spinal tuberculosis. This indicates the destruction of the intervertebral disc due to spinal tuberculosis.

The infection first involves the vertebral bodies and the intervertebral disc. Hence, the early radiographic features include rarefaction/osteopenic appearance of the involved vertebrae and reduction of disc space between the vertebrae.

In later stages, the infection leads to para-vertebral abscess formation and vertebral destruction. These features can be seen on a radiograph as bird’s nest abscess and anterior wedging of vertebrae respectively.

When the disease is in the healing phase, the sclerotic appearance of vertebrae can be seen.

questions.text: The following image reflects the histopathology of ______
questions.solution:
The image shows histopathology of aneurysmal bone cyst.

It consists of multiple blood filled cystic spaces separated by tan white septa. The walls are composed of plump uniform fibroblasts, multi-nucleated osteoclast giant cells, and reactive woven bone. The bone is lined by osteoblast cells.

In Giant cell tumour, sheets of uniform spindle to oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei are seen.

The following image shows histology of giant cell tumour.

questions.text: Why is an osteochondroma not considered a true neoplasm?

choices.text: The bony prominence has a cartilage capping
The lesion is angled away from the growth plate
It stops growing with cessation of the growth at the Epiphyseal plate

questions.solution:
• An osteochondroma is not considered a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the Epiphyseal plate.
  • They are developmental malformations which are thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain and swelling over the knee joint. There is stiffness of the knee joint. The X-ray picture of the patient is given below. A chest radiograph showed right upper lobe airspace disease with associated hilar adenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Young female with pain, swelling and stiffness at the knee joint, along with right upper lobe airspace disease, hilar lymphadenopathy with the knee x ray showing joint space destruction and marked periarticular rarefaction is suggestive of tubercular arthritis.

In case of synovial tuberculosis, which is most common site; the x-ray is most often normal. There may be a soft tissue shadow corresponding to the distended knee. The joint space could be initially widened. A diffuse osteoporosis of the bones around the joint is also seen. 

Marked periarticular rarefaction is seen.

When the origin of the disease is osseous, there are lytic lesions. In late stages, the joint space is reduced or even completely lost. In the end stages, even triple deformity with cavitations of the bone may be visible.

Pigmented villonodular synovitis (PVNS) is a joint disease characterized by inflammation and overgrowth of the synovium.

questions.text: What are rotationally unstable, but vertically stable pelvic ring fractures classified as?
questions.solution:
Rotationally unstable, but vertically stable pelvic ring fractures are classified as Tile type B. 

Two classification systems are used in the evaluation of pelvic ring fractures:

1. The Tile classification provides an assessment of the stability of the pelvis. It helps the surgeon predict the need for surgery. Pelvic ring fractures are classified into 3 types: 

Tile classification Stability Management
Type A Rotationally and vertically stable Conservative
Type B Rotationally unstable and vertically stable External fixation is used for definitive management. Anterior fixation is additionally done if pubic bones have separated by more than 2.5 cm.
Type C Rotationally and vertically unstable  Posterior fixation is done for vertical stability along with external fixation.

2. The Young and Burgess classification is based on the mechanism of injury. It helps the surgeon predict the severity of the injury, blood loss, and deformity or displacement. 

Note: Neer classification is used for proximal humerus fractures.

questions.text: This is the chest X-ray of a 30-year-old male who presented with back pain and weight loss. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: The X-ray shows bird nest abscess
There is mediastinal widening in a patient with Pott's spine
The width of the abscess is greater than its length
It is more commonly associated with paraplegia

questions.solution:
The X-ray clearly shows an abscess in the paravertebral region (bird nest abscess–length is greater than its width).

It indicates pus under pressure and is commonly associated with paraplegia.

An abscess from the dorsal spine may present as widened mediastinum. Globular or tense abscess–an abscess whose width is greater than the length.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presented with low back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination of the spine, a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has spondylolisthesis. A palpable step in the lumbosacral spine is a classic clinical feature of this condition.  It is known as step sign.

Normally, the spinous processes of the adjacent vertebrae are aligned with each other. They can be palpated on the back in a smooth way.

In spondylolisthesis, one vertebra has moved over the other. Therefore, a step-off or step sign can be felt over the spinous process at the affected level. 

Note: The step-off sign is also used to describe the radiographic appearance of Lisfranc injury of the foot. There is a dorsal displacement of the tarsal bones with respect to the metatarsal bones.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding acute compartment syndrome of the forearm?

choices.text: It is defined by compartment pressure of >30 mm of Hg
Whiteside’s technique is used to measure compartment pressure
Mobile wad of Henry compartment is most commonly involved
Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Mobile wad of Henry refers to the lateral compartment of the forearm and is not commonly associated in acute compartment syndrome. Volar (anterior) compartment is most commonly involved.

Whiteside described a technique for measuring compartment pressures using an 18-gauge needle, saline syringe, three-way stopcock, and a mercury manometer.

Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice and should be performed when the difference between compartment and diastolic pressure is less than 30 mm of mercury or if compartment pressure is more than 30 mmhg.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause for thoracic outlet syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cleidocranial dysostosis does not cause thoracic outlet syndrome.

Tumor arising from the upper lobe of the lung (eg: Pancoast tumor), cervicothoracic scoliosis, and malunion or nonunion of fracture clavicle are causes of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A 28-year-old archer presents with complaints of weakness of the shoulder and tingling sensation in his fingers while in the full draw position. You suspect thoracic outlet syndrome.  All of the following are provocative tests for this condition, except:
questions.solution:
Jobe's test is not a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome. Jobe's test is performed to evaluate for shoulder impingement syndrome.

The provocative tests for thoracic outlet syndrome include Adson's test, Wright's test, and Roos's test.

questions.text: Choose the true statement regarding the natural history of skeletal tuberculosis:

choices.text: Bone and joint Tuberculosis are mostly secondary
Demineralisation of bone occurs due to intense local hyperemia
The infected granulation tissue and pus localizes in the sub-periosteal and soft tissue planes in the form of abscesses

questions.solution:
Bone and joint tuberculosis are almost always secondary to some primary focus in the lungs, lymphnodes etc. Mode of spread from the primary focus may be either hematigenous or by direct extension.

Inflammation as a result of TB results in trabecular necrosis and caseation. The intense local hyperemia leads to demineralization of the bone. If there is no interference at this stage, then the cortex also gets eroded. The infected granulation tissue and pus track beneath the subperiosteal planes and soft tissue planes, resulting in the formation of a cold abscess.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple painless swellings over the costochondral junction. Which of the following conditions is least likely in this child?
questions.solution:
Multiple painless swellings at the costochondral junction is suggestive of rachitic rosary in this child. It is not seen in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Rachitic rosary is seen in rickets and all the conditions leading to hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia. Hemangiopericytoma causes hypophosphataemic vitamin D-resistant rickets.

questions.text: Select the false statement regarding electromyograph.

choices.text: A normal muscle at rest shows no electrical activity
Interference pattern is seen in a strong contraction
A denervated muscle shows electrical activity at rest
Denervation potentials appearing within 2 weeks after a nerve injury is a good prognostic sign

questions.solution:
The denervated muscle has spontaneous electrical activity at rest called denervation potentials.. These appear at around 15-20 days after muscle denervation.

If these potentials ‘have not appeared by the second week of nerve injury, it is a good prognostic sign’.

EMG is the graphic recording of the electrical activity of a muscle at rest and during activity.

  • A normal muscle at rest shows no electrical activity.
  • With voluntary contraction, action potentials develop in the motor units.
  • In a strong contraction, impulses of a number of motor units firing simultaneously are super-imposed, giving rise to an interference pattern.
